name: Group Properties
what: This subtopic covers the specific properties and reactions of four important groups: alkali metals (Group 1), alkaline earth metals (Group 2), halogens (Group 17), and noble gases (Group 18).
why: These groups demonstrate clear patterns that illustrate periodic trends. Understanding their properties helps you apply general principles to predict behaviour of specific elements.

items.title: I can describe the properties and reactions of alkali metals
items.what: Group 1 metals are soft, have low melting points, and react vigorously with water to produce hydrogen gas and a metal hydroxide solution. Reactivity increases down the group.
items.why: Alkali metals demonstrate the trend of increasing metal reactivity down a group and show how having one valence electron leads to predictable behaviour.
items.example: Sodium reacts with water: sodium + water â†’ sodium hydroxide + hydrogen. The reaction produces fizzing (hydrogen gas) and the solution turns phenolphthalein pink (basic).

items.title: I can describe the properties and reactions of alkaline earth metals
items.what: Group 2 metals are harder than Group 1 metals and also react with water, though less vigorously. They have two valence electrons and form 2+ ions.
items.why: Comparing Groups 1 and 2 shows how the number of valence electrons affects reactivity. It takes more energy to remove two electrons than one.
items.example: Magnesium reacts slowly with cold water but vigorously with steam: magnesium + water â†’ magnesium hydroxide + hydrogen.

items.title: I can describe the properties and reactions of halogens
items.what: Group 17 elements are reactive non-metals that exist as diatomic molecules (Fâ‚‚, Clâ‚‚, Brâ‚‚, Iâ‚‚). They gain one electron to form 1- ions. Reactivity decreases down the group.
items.why: Halogens show the opposite reactivity trend to metals because they gain electrons rather than lose them. Smaller atoms gain electrons more easily.
items.example: Chlorine is a yellow-green gas, bromine is a brown liquid, and iodine is a purple-grey solid at room temperature. All are toxic.

items.title: I can explain why noble gases are unreactive
items.what: Group 18 elements have full outer shells (2 for helium, 8 for others). They do not need to gain or lose electrons to achieve stability, so they rarely react.
items.why: Noble gases represent the stable electron configuration that all other elements are trying to achieve through chemical reactions.
items.example: Neon has electron configuration 2,8 with a full outer shell. It does not react with other elements because it is already stable.

items.title: I can predict displacement reactions between halogens
items.what: A more reactive halogen will displace a less reactive halogen from its compound. Chlorine displaces bromine; bromine displaces iodine; but iodine cannot displace chlorine or bromine.
items.why: Displacement reactions provide evidence for the reactivity series and demonstrate competition for electrons between elements.
items.example: When chlorine water is added to potassium bromide solution, the solution turns orange as chlorine displaces bromine: Clâ‚‚ + 2KBr â†’ 2KCl + Brâ‚‚.

items.title: I can write word equations for reactions of metals with water and chlorine
items.what: Metals react with water to produce metal hydroxide and hydrogen gas. Metals react with chlorine to produce metal chloride. These are predictable patterns.
items.why: Being able to write reaction equations demonstrates understanding of what products form and allows you to predict unfamiliar reactions.
items.example: Potassium + water â†’ potassium hydroxide + hydrogen. Potassium + chlorine â†’ potassium chloride.
